title: 106_hr909
content: The Act may be cited as the "Y2K State and Local GAP (Government Assistance Programs) Act of 1999". It includes definitions for various terms used in the Act. The Act, known as the "Y2K State and Local GAP Act of 1999," defines various welfare programs including TANF, Medicaid, food stamps, WIC, child support enforcement, and child welfare programs. The curr_chunk discusses the definition of "Y2K compliant" in relation to information technology accurately processing date and time data between the 20th and 21st centuries. It also mentions various welfare programs such as child support enforcement, child welfare programs, and the Child Care and Development Block Grant Act of 1990. Grants are provided to states for ensuring state and local government programs are Y2K compliant. The Secretary of Commerce awards grants to States for Y2K compliance in state and local government programs. Priority is given to requests related to Federal welfare programs. Limitations include a maximum of 75 grants and 2 grants per State. Applications must be submitted within 45 days of enactment through the State Governor's Office. The Secretary of Commerce awards grants to States for Y2K compliance in state and local government programs. Applications must be submitted within the constraints set by the Secretary of Commerce. The application should include a proposed plan, budget, funding source, and a matching requirement for grant approval. States awarded a grant under this section must expend $1 for every $2 awarded to develop and implement a Y2K compliance program. The Secretary of Commerce can waive the matching requirement for states facing undue hardship. State expenditures can be in cash or in kind, including equipment or services. The Secretary of Commerce evaluates grant applications based on feasibility and achieving program goals. Grants awarded under this section are limited to a maximum of 2 years. State funds from grants remain available without a fiscal year limit. (d) Grants awarded under this section are limited to a maximum of 2 years. Funds provided to a State under a grant shall remain available until expended without fiscal year limitation. States must submit annual and final reports on the compliance program funded under the grant. $40,000,000 is authorized for fiscal years 1999 to 2001 to carry out this section.
